input_text.Prompt: Can you tell me how to improve media relations at an ad agency?
input_text.Response A: Sure, I’m happy to help.  What do you think is the biggest problem you’re facing right now?
input_text.Response B:
Of course.  I can’t tell you exactly how to do it, since I don’t have any experience with an ad agency.  But I can tell you a few things that may be relevant, based on my general knowledge of the world.  

First, if you want to improve media relations at your agency, you might start by assessing how the current state of media relations is affecting the agency’s bottom line.  For example, if the agency’s reputation is suffering, or if the agency is having a hard time winning new business, that will probably be a good indicator that the media relations work needs to be improved.  

Second, you might think about why the media relations work is being done in the first place.  If the goal is to help the agency win new business, you’ll want to make sure that your media relations work is helping with that.  If the goal is to help the agency improve its reputation, you’ll want to make sure that the media relations work is having a positive effect on the agency’s reputation.  

Third, you might think about whether the current state of media relations is consistent with the agency’s values.  For example, if the agency prides itself on being a cutting-edge, innovative place, it might be worth considering whether the current media relations work is helping the agency to achieve that goal.  

Finally, you might want to think about how the media relations work is being done.  If the agency has a great reputation and is winning new business successfully, you might want to think about whether the current media relations work is being done effectively.  If the agency has a poor reputation and isn’t winning new business successfully, you might want to think about whether the current media relations work is being done ineffectively.
